definition: to call out (a name etc)/to shout
to call/to cry/to shout/to breath out/to exhale

sentences.english: The voice of the mournful chanter called to dolorous prayer.
sentences.chinese: 哀慟的領唱人的聲音向哀傷的禱告者呼喚。

sentences.english: Inter-party forum calls for global reform .
sentences.chinese: 中歐政黨高層論壇呼喚全球改革。

sentences.english: Strongly appeal on the change in the role of primary school teachers in curriculum innovation.
sentences.chinese: 新課改對小學語文教師角色轉變的呼喚異常強烈。

sentences.english: The 21st century calls for innovative talents.
Somebody is calling us in the distance.
The times of "returning to faith" appeal to advocate moral belief education.
sentences.chinese: 迴歸信仰的時代籲求呼喚道德信仰教育。

sentences.english: I had hoped that the landowner would have heeded that call.
sentences.chinese: 我希望地主能注意到這樣的呼喚。

sentences.english: I waited very breifly, then started to make a phone call.
sentences.chinese: 我就等了一小會兒，便開始呼喚神。

sentences.english: Wulin through stories, a dragon 18 zhangs variation unsummon resection.
sentences.chinese: 武林能手的穿越故事，降龍十八掌變異爲呼喚術。

sentences.english: Francine: Listen. There are moments when life calls out for a change.
sentences.chinese: 聽着，有些時刻生活呼喚着需要有變化。

sentences.english: Cry as loud as you can, your dreams may come back.
sentences.chinese: 放聲地呼喚吧，飄遠的夢想會歸來。

sentences.english: It is here within my Immaculate Heart I call you.
sentences.chinese: 我在我的無玷聖心中呼喚你們。

sentences.english: She also ignored his call as she pushed through the double glass doors.
sentences.chinese: 她匆匆穿過雙扇玻璃門，對身後的呼喚也置若罔聞。

sentences.english: This request consists in a scientific spirit and unity of humanity.
sentences.chinese: 這種呼喚體現了科學精神與人道精神的統一。

sentences.english: By the afternoon, the park is calling us.
sentences.chinese: 下午的時候，公園像是在呼喚着我們。

sentences.english: The calling for the spiritual growth reflects the deep thinking frow the author.
sentences.chinese: 對精神成長的深切呼喚，彰顯出小說的思想深度。

definition: to hug/to cherish/within the bosom (of the family)/to embrace (also fig. an ideal, aspiration etc)
to recount/to tell of/to relate/(fig.) (of a thing) to stand as testament to (some past history)
plural marker for pronouns, and nouns referring to individuals
